repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Education for All (EFA) Fast
            Track Initiative Catalytic Fund Grant Project :
            environmental and social management framework (ESMF)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project development objective of the
            Education for All (EFA) Fast Track Initiative Catalytic Fund
            Grant Project is to support the Government of Lesotho: (i)
            in consolidating the gains obtained in primary education
            enrollment of boys and girls; (ii) in improving quality in
            primary education; and (iii) in expanding pro-poor
            pre-primary education; through improvements in school
            infrastructure, improved distribution of qualified teachers,
            interventions to enhance the quality of teaching, and
            improved access to reception classes. Negative impacts
            include: soil erosion, water resources, air quality, natural
            habitats, and fauna and flora. Mitigation measures include:
            1) construction in dry season; protection of soil surfaces
            during construction; re-vegetation or physical stabilization
            of erodable surfaces; 2) proper disposal of chemicals and
            other hazardous materials; 3) special attention to drainage;
            prevention of erosion; consideration of alternative
            alignments; retention ponds; proper disposal of oil and
            other hazardous materials; 4) slung of latrines at safe
            distances from wells and using closed systems for sewage
            drainage; and 5) restoration of vegetation; cleanup of
            construction sites.

repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Second Education Sector
            Development Project (Phase Two)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Education Sector
            Development Project for Lesotho are as follows: outcomes of
            the project were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, bank performance was
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: use of
            implementation arrangements outside of the public service
            structures created difficulties of sustainability. Despite
            the intentions at appraisal, the Project Support and
            Coordination Unit (PSCU) became the de facto implementing
            agency for the project and for other Ministry of Education
            and Training (MoET) functions. Once established, it was
            allowed to grow rapidly. While effective in implementing the
            core tasks, the PSCU did little to build capacity within the
            ministry. In fact, any failures in the ministry were seen as
            strengthening the case for continuation of the PSCU. The
            reluctance to address this issue on time, and to develop a
            realistic transition strategy, has resulted in a much more
            abrupt transition than would otherwise have been the case,
            with consequent disruption to the work of the MoET. Building
            capacity within the MoET remains a challenge. Provision of
            training courses has had some impact, but the benefits were
            eroded by staff turnover and by organizational structures
            which prevented optimal use of the skilled personnel.
            Building better organizational structures is likely to take
            some time, and some external assistance may be required to
            ensure efficient operation of the MoET. However, future
            external assistance should be carefully managed to ensure
            that it supports capacity building aims and cannot become a
            separate arm of the ministry.

repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Second Education Sector
            Development Project (Phase 02)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Development Objective of the
            proposed Second Education Sector Development Project (Phase
            02) is to further improve the access, equity, and quality of
            primary and secondary education, promote lifelong learning
            through building capacity in early childhood, technical and
            vocational, higher and non-formal education, and
            strengthening the institutional capacity of the Ministry of
            Education and Training. The following are components to the
            project. Primary Education: 1) This component will finance
            252 primary classrooms with related facilities including
            administrative block, kitchen, latrines, and standard
            classroom furniture. 2) This component will annually finance
            up to 15,000 bursaries to orphans and other disadvantaged
            children in upper primary and lower secondary grades. 3)
            this component will support the additional core primary
            textbooks needed to cater for new primary enrolment. 3) This
            component will finance the development of a secondary core
            textbook rental scheme and revolving fund, and the purchase
            of the initial start-up stock for the rental scheme. 4).
            This component will finance (a) a refresher course for
            primary teachers in core subjects once every two years and
            (b) annual training of primary inspectors and advisors. 5)
            This component will finance the continuous training of
            school management (principals and their deputies, and
            primary management committees). 6) Distance Teacher
            Education Program. As of 2001, about 25% of Lesotho's
            8225 primary teachers are still not qualified, meaning they
            have a below diploma level education. 7) This component will
            finance the continued development of an Integrated
            Curriculum and Examination Framework, localization of the
            Cambridge Overseas School Certificate Exam and
            implementation of the National Standardized Tests in basic
            literacy and numeracy. Components for Secondary Education:
            1) This component will finance the construction of at least
            3 secondary schools with related facilities, furniture, and
            equipment. 2) This component will annually finance up to
            15000 bursaries to orphans and other disadvantaged children
            in upper primary and secondary grades. 3) This component
            will finance the development of a secondary core textbook
            rental scheme and revolving fund and the purchase of the
            initial start-up stock for the rental scheme. 4) This
            component will finance (a) a refresher course for secondary
            teachers of Math, English, Science, and Sesotho once every
            two years and (b) annual training of secondary inspectors
            and advisors. 5) This component will finance the continuous
            training of secondary school.

repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Second Education Sector
            Development Project - APL Phase Two : environmental and
            social management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Sector Development
            Project - APL Phase Two for Lesotho will finance the
            construction of new primary schools, the expansion of
            existing secondary schools, and a new one hundred bed hostel
            facility for male and female students at Thaba Tseka
            Technical Institute. However, since the exact locations for
            these new schools were not identified at the time the
            project was being prepared, the assessment of future
            potential environmental and social impacts, and mitigation
            measures were diminished. Each location that will be
            subsequently identified and approved, will be subject to
            environmental and social planning prior to approval. The
            environmental and social planning for the construction of
            schools will be the instrument through which the project
            activities, environmental, and social impacts are identified
            and assessed and would also evaluate alternatives, and
            design appropriate mitigation, management and monitoring
            measures. The Environment and Social Management Framework
            (ESMF) will present a framework for screening, monitoring
            and mitigating potential impacts.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Sector Development
            Project - APL Phase Two for Lesotho will finance the
            construction of new primary schools, the expansion of
            existing secondary schools, and a new one hundred bed hostel
            facility for male and female students at Thaba Tseka
            Technical Institute. As the exact locations for the new
            schools were not identified at the time the project was
            being prepared, the exact numbers and situations of affected
            persons are not addressed in this framework. The
            resettlement policy framework covers: the principles and
            objectives concerning resettlement preparation and
            implementation; land acquisitions; eligibility criteria
            project affected persons; a review of the legal framework;
            methods of valuing affected assets; organizational
            procedures for the delivery of entitlements; descriptions of
            the process for preparing and approving resettlement plans,
            of the implementation process, the grievance redress
            mechanisms, funding arrangements, and consultation
            mechanisms; and monitoring arrangements.
